q.q: Do you have any tips for syncing music up to dialogues and actions in videos?

q.a: one good trick is to press record (with your clip synced up) and watch it and just sort of play it, after. with the right timing. so just as soon as you see the action, look away from the screen and imagine what you just saw in your head and play it synced to that, so it will be timed right, but just a bit delayed. then just go in and move it. if it's not quite right, just do it again. or if it's midi then just nudge notes to fit. fuck it, nowadays you can nudge audio notes too anyways
q.q: I'd love to be able to take video clips and give them a musical score where everything is in sync with the dialogue/action of what's going on the video (like if someone's walking downstairs I could have percussion hits that match the footsteps exactly, etc) are there any tricks to this?

Like how in your non-song vids youll have little musical cues and effects that sync up perfectly in time to graphics that are flashing on the screen or whatever.. Do you try thinking of the video as being at a certain bpm/time signature and using that for knowing when to come in, or is it just about watching the video a bunch of times and doing a bunch of takes until you get the timing right? Eventually, I wanna learn how to do animation and make my own videos, but I want to work on the music-side first by just setting music to clips from old movies or any other random stuff I can find.

q.a: i've just been familiar with them for so long i don't have a strategy. but i will teach you one to get you started, forgive me if you already know this one, and if you do i will tell you the next one. but the chord is called C major, or just "C" for short. and it is when you play the notes C, E, and G, at the same time, somewhere in the middle range of the keyboard (it doesn't count if you play all 3 notes in the bass range, that is just called mud. if there are any notes in the bass range it should be just 1 and it should be the C note.)  so again this is called C major, or "C" for short. if middle C is on the bottom, that's fine. if middle C is in the middle, with G under it and E above it, that is fine (there might also be C in the bass range as well). it might be middle C on top, with G and E right under it (that is probably about as low as you might go for the C chord). it could be higher, with E330(hz) then G and C above it. all these combinations are still called C, or C major. (C as a chord automatically means C major.) I hope that is enough to get you started, forgive me if you already knew all that. if you want to know more i will tell you

q.a: use the knuckles method. hold out your hands, palm down. make fists. look at the top of your knuckles. look at the knuckles and the spaces in between the knuckles. start counting the months from the left, with a month for each knuckle and space. the knuckles represent long months (31) and the spaces represent short months (30 or less). you will see they alternate until you reach the last knuckle (july), then you have to jump to your other hand and that's another knuckle (august) and keep going from there until you run out of months (december)
